claim: A 62-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of an unintended 10-pound weight loss over the last 4 months. He also reports vague abdominal discomfort, weakness, and occasional yellowing of his skin and eyes. He has a history of cirrhosis secondary to alcohol abuse and hepatitis C infection. Physical exam demonstrates hepatomegaly and abdominal distention. Which of the following serum markers is most strongly associated with this patient’s condition? : Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)

supporting.text: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker often elevated in colorectal cancer, but it is not specific to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which is more likely in this patient with cirrhosis and hepatitis C.

attacks.text: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker often elevated in colorectal cancer, but it is not specific to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which is more likely in this patient with cirrhosis and hepatitis C.
CEA can still be elevated in HCC, especially in advanced cases, and should not be entirely dismissed as a diagnostic marker.
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a more specific and sensitive marker for HCC compared to CEA, making it the preferred choice in this clinical scenario.
While CEA may be elevated in some HCC cases, its lack of specificity reduces its clinical utility compared to AFP, which has a stronger association with HCC.
AFP is not only more specific for HCC but also correlates with tumor burden and prognosis, further supporting its superiority over CEA in this context.
Even if CEA is elevated in advanced HCC, its diagnostic value is limited by the high prevalence of false positives in other conditions, such as inflammatory bowel disease or smoking.

Some HCC tumors do not produce AFP, leading to false-negative results in certain cases.
Despite its limitations, AFP remains the most widely used and clinically relevant marker for HCC surveillance in high-risk patients like this one.
Modern imaging techniques combined with AFP measurement significantly improve the diagnostic accuracy for HCC.
Even with imaging, small or early-stage HCC lesions may be missed, and AFP levels could still be normal.
Other biomarkers like PIVKA-II or AFP-L3% may provide better specificity but are not as widely available as AFP.
